Award.AwardTitle: Integrated Models of Mantle Convection and True Polar Wander, and the Structure of the Earth's Deep Interior
Award.AbstractNarration:
The interior of the Earth cools over geological time through the process of thermal convection. Slow creeping flow allows hot material to rise and cold material to sink. This large-scale circulation is responsible for building mountains and driving most of the geological processes we observe at the surface. The Earth also rotates in space, and the orientation of the spin axis evolves slowly with time due to a redistribution of mass associated with thermal convection. Changes in the spin axis, known as true polar wander, are detected in paleomagnetic observations and are attributed to thermal convection. However, it is generally assumed that rotation has little influence on thermal convection. Several new lines of evidence challenge this conventional view. Plate motions are spatially correlated with the orientation of the rotation axis. In addition, the Earth's deep interior has peculiar features that reside on the equator and appear to be affected by rotation. We propose to investigate the dynamic interaction between thermal convection and true polar wander with the aim of better understanding these two fundamental processes.

The proposed research will integrate thermal convection and true polar wander into a single, self-consistent description of planetary dynamics. Numerical models of thermal convection are normally based on a set of equations that describe conservation of mass, heat and linear momentum, whereas models of true polar wander are invariably based on conservation of angular momentum. By expanding and generalizing the usual description of thermal convection, we have combined these two processes into a single set of equations that permit full interaction between convection and true polar wander. We plan to solve these equations numerically by adding new capability to an existing community software package called ASPECT, which was developed with support from NSF. All developments undertaken during this project will be made available to the community through the Computational Infrastructure for Geodynamics (www.geodynamics.org). The software will be useful to other researchers for a wide range of potential applications, including the thermal and chemical evolution of continental lithosphere. The proposed research will also contribute to the training of graduate students and young researchers in advanced computational methods.

ProgramReference.Text: STUDIES OF THE EARTH'S DEEP INTERIOR

POR.DRECONTENT:
Geological and paleomagnetic observations suggest that the Earth has occasionally experienced periods of rapid true polar wander, in which the geographic location of the rotation axis changes over timescales of millions of years. In some cases the location of the rotation axis can change by 90 degrees with dramatic consequences for life in the geological past. In this project we developed a new, integrated theory of true polar wander and mantle convection. These two topics have been generally treated separately in the past, but they are actually different expressions of the same underlying dynamics. The theoretical developments in this project explicitly links the two processes and applies the principles of dimensional analysis to provide a concise and complete description of the processes. The dimenional analysis allows to extrapolate the predicted behavior to other times in Earth history (say when the vigor of convection was greater) or to other bodies (such as Mars or the Moon). One of the conclusions of this work is that periods of rapid true polar wander are likely more frequent than previously thought. Indeed, the so-called inertial interchange events (commonly associated with rapid true polar wander) are just an end-member of a broader spectrum of behavior. A second important conclusion is that intervals of rapid true polar wander were more frequent in Earth's past due to a higher vigor of convection.

Numerical implementations of true polar wander and mantle convection require a reliable treatment of a free surface; a surface that is able to change position in response to the underlying dynamics. Two implementations of a free-surface condition were developed in this project and incorporated into community mantle-convection model called ASPECT. One approach is based on the concept of non-standard finite differences. Implementing this approach required only modest changes to the software, but proved effective in numerical tests. A second approach based on a previously published, quasi-implicit scheme, as also implemented for the first time in ASPECT. The second approach required more code development, but it also proved effective. This software is now available to other researchers who use the community ASPECT code.
